title: Job woes rattle Obama's strategy
content:
Obama ’ s campaign hopes have always hinged on a steadily improving economy . Job woes rattle Obama 's strategy
President Barack Obama had hoped to make the 2012 campaign a referendum on Mitt Romney ’ s Bain record , Massachusetts stumbles and what Obama ’ s team sees as Romney ’ s robotic oddness — but the economy has other ideas .
Never mind battleground polls , super PAC spending or the number of campaign offices opened in the greater Columbus , Ohio , metropolitan area . The only metrics that matter to Obama — jobs created and lost — are suddenly headed in a very dangerous direction .
Obama ’ s campaign hopes have always hinged on a steadily improving economy and a growing sense that things are moving in the right direction after the Bush hangover . Earlier this year , the economy seemed to be cooperating .
But May ’ s 69,000 job-creation number , an unemployment uptick to 8.2 percent and downward revisions on earlier , rosier reports have upended that rationale . Renewed concerns about the global recovery , compounded by the slow-motion fiscal train wreck in Europe , a slowdown in China and Friday ’ s Dow selloff that put the index in negative territory for the year have seriously undercut Obama ’ s main reelection strategy : Making the race a referendum on Romney .
Obama said Friday in Golden Valley , Minn. , that while the economy is “ not growing as fast as we want it to grow … we will come back stronger ; we do have better days ahead . ”
But time is running out for a “ V ” shaped upturn that would power Obama to a second term .
“ The president has to address what he is going to do to change things , rather than staying the same policy course he charted which has brought us to this point , ” GOP pollster David Winston said .
“ This was a bad report , not only in terms of the limited jobs created and the increase in the unemployment rate but the revision downward of the previous two months as well . This comes on top of the economic growth rate being revised downward to 1.9 percent . ”
The lousy report seemed like a flashback to 2011 , when an encouraging spring led to a disappointing summer jobs picture , especially among young people — a core Obama constituency . Teenagers , according to the May report , now have an unemployment rate approaching 25 percent .
Republicans — unbowed by Obama ’ s charge that they are rooting for failure — greeted the numbers with a barrage of emails , press releases and media availabilities . House Majority Leader Eric Cantor ( R-Va. ) called the report “ pathetic , ” while a hoarse Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) shouted , “ Why don ’ t they pick up the bills and pass them ? ” — a reference to the jobs bills introduced by Republicans in lieu of Obama ’ s own stymied jobs package .
And Romney — whose Boston campaign office is festooned with mock street signs touting the overly optimistic job creation claim of the 2009 stimulus — released a strongly worded statement minutes after the numbers posted on a federal Web site .
“ Today ’ s weak jobs report is devastating news for American workers and American families , ” Romney said . “ This week has seen a cascade of one bad piece of economic news after another . Slowing GDP growth , plunging consumer confidence , an increase in unemployment claims , and now another dismal jobs report all stand as a harsh indictment of the president ’ s handling of the economy . … The president ’ s re-election slogan may be ‘ forward , ’ but it seems like we ’ ve been moving backward .
“ We can do so much better in America . That ’ s why I ’ m running for president . ”

Obama’s campaign hopes have always hinged on a steadily improving economy. Job woes rattle Obama's strategy

President Barack Obama had hoped to make the 2012 campaign a referendum on Mitt Romney’s Bain record, Massachusetts stumbles and what Obama’s team sees as Romney’s robotic oddness — but the economy has other ideas.

Never mind battleground polls, super PAC spending or the number of campaign offices opened in the greater Columbus, Ohio, metropolitan area. The only metrics that matter to Obama — jobs created and lost — are suddenly headed in a very dangerous direction.

Story Continued Below

Obama’s campaign hopes have always hinged on a steadily improving economy and a growing sense that things are moving in the right direction after the Bush hangover. Earlier this year, the economy seemed to be cooperating.

But May’s 69,000 job-creation number, an unemployment uptick to 8.2 percent and downward revisions on earlier, rosier reports have upended that rationale. Renewed concerns about the global recovery, compounded by the slow-motion fiscal train wreck in Europe, a slowdown in China and Friday’s Dow selloff that put the index in negative territory for the year have seriously undercut Obama’s main reelection strategy: Making the race a referendum on Romney.

Obama said Friday in Golden Valley, Minn., that while the economy is “not growing as fast as we want it to grow … we will come back stronger; we do have better days ahead.”

But time is running out for a “V” shaped upturn that would power Obama to a second term.

“The president has to address what he is going to do to change things, rather than staying the same policy course he charted which has brought us to this point,” GOP pollster David Winston said.

“This was a bad report, not only in terms of the limited jobs created and the increase in the unemployment rate but the revision downward of the previous two months as well. This comes on top of the economic growth rate being revised downward to 1.9 percent.”

The lousy report seemed like a flashback to 2011, when an encouraging spring led to a disappointing summer jobs picture, especially among young people — a core Obama constituency. Teenagers, according to the May report, now have an unemployment rate approaching 25 percent.

Republicans — unbowed by Obama’s charge that they are rooting for failure — greeted the numbers with a barrage of emails, press releases and media availabilities. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) called the report “pathetic,” while a hoarse Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) shouted, “Why don’t they pick up the bills and pass them?” — a reference to the jobs bills introduced by Republicans in lieu of Obama’s own stymied jobs package.

And Romney — whose Boston campaign office is festooned with mock street signs touting the overly optimistic job creation claim of the 2009 stimulus — released a strongly worded statement minutes after the numbers posted on a federal Web site.

“Today’s weak jobs report is devastating news for American workers and American families,” Romney said. “This week has seen a cascade of one bad piece of economic news after another. Slowing GDP growth, plunging consumer confidence, an increase in unemployment claims, and now another dismal jobs report all stand as a harsh indictment of the president’s handling of the economy. … The president’s re-election slogan may be ‘forward,’ but it seems like we’ve been moving backward.

“We can do so much better in America. That’s why I’m running for president.”
